items.title: Layout Animations with Framer motion
items.author: Oluwabori hamzat
items.description:
One of the significant differences between a boring user experience and a good one is animations. Not just fade-in animations but animations with context(such as micro animations in icons or buttons and Layout animations).

Layout animation which is my focus is really of importance, because the attention of the user often follows animations. But the current state of the web doesnâ€™t support layout effects. Weâ€™ve always seen layout animations on mobile apps, when we click on a card then it pops up giving more details, and the experience is quite enjoyable Youâ€™re always sure of what to do next. but on the web, you get something likeÂ this.

ğŸ˜¤ğŸ˜¤ annoying isnâ€™t it. The user interface just threw the user into an ocean of doubts and questionsâ€” â€œwhat am I going to do next?â€, â€œIs this the element I clicked on?â€. These sorts of questions are what prompted me to writeÂ this.

We would implement a solution to this problem with react, typescript(very minimal), Stitches.js (a CSS in JS library), and framer motion, our animation library. First, we build our user interface, nothing complex just a centered grid with 2 columns andÂ cards.

1. Building the user interface

We import the necessary libraries

https://medium.com/media/b3929118573e74269d6296196b92bb18/href

we then get the data for components you can get all the images from the GitHub repository.

https://medium.com/media/36ca65ad8f6e50264b44c17efd47a3dc/href

then we create our base components, it doesnâ€™t have to be in the sameÂ file.

https://medium.com/media/4efacedaa90a8a050034d22fa6c6699f/href

the syntax of stitches is just like most CSS-in-JS frameworks, with a twistâ€Šâ€”â€ŠStitches has a fully-typed API that gives it the best Developer Experience. Composing all of these little parts together, we build the user interface

https://medium.com/media/2d3b19397646bc7ac6320e59e3a94e71/href

The code is simple. we created a state to store the id of the selected item(for those new to typescript the <undefined | number> is just to indicate that type of the constant selected can either be a number or undefined) and we built the user interface with the base components. This is theÂ result

Itâ€™s functional but without animations. To add animation to it will have to make use of the motion component.

2. Adding animations

now that weâ€™ve updated our base components, we have to make use of the properties given to us by the motion component. The properties of concern are layoutId and layoutÂ . with layoutId property framer-motion can identify the element and if the position of the element changes in the DOM it animates the elements(so far the layoutId stays the same). This might be a lot to take in at first but in practice is far too easy. So we add the layoutId to the Card component.

the results?

better right? We can notice that the elements in the background were animated to fill up the space but the MainCard didnâ€™t animate at all. thatâ€™s because the MainCard doesnâ€™t have the layoutId of the selected card(i.e the card that was removed from the DOM). By adding this we get the animation weâ€™ve been lookingÂ for.

the results?

weâ€™ve finally seen what we want. You can see how easy it is to build layout animations with framer-motion. this is the code for theÂ app

https://medium.com/media/2384baab1d401198db563d2884ff181a/href

3. HindSight

we could have added a placeholder for the Card which is selected to prevent the unnecessary movement of the otherÂ cards.
